document.masterDocTitle: A revision of the Southern African species of Meliturgula Friese (Hymenoptera: Andrenidae: Panurginae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A revision of the Southern African species of Meliturgula Friese (Hymenoptera: Andrenidae: Panurginae)

subSubSection.paragraph: Named for Derek Bonheim, who has been a friend for more than 40 years.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Meliturgula bonheimi
sp.n. , female: a. Face. b. Habitus, dorsal view. c. Habitus, lateral view. d. Pygidial plate.

subSubSection.paragraph:
This species belongs to
Meliturgula s.str.
This subgenus displays two distinct forms; one characterized by
Meliturgula braunsi
, the other by
M. scriptifrons
.
Meliturgula bonheimi
is more similar to
M. scriptifrons
in the convexity of the clypeus, narrow facial fovea and divided propodeum. Within this group only
M. bonheimi
and
M. scriptifrons
have a glabrous ridge separating the anterior and posterior surfaces of the propodeum. By contrast, the extensive yellow facial maculation of
M. bonheimi
resembles
M. braunsi ,
as does the curved posterior edge of the first submarginal cell.

Diagnosis . Lower region of face mostly yellow (
Fig. 1
a), facial fovea narrow, propodeum distinctly divided ( cf.
Fig. 4
d), metasoma mostly orange (
Figs 1
b–d).

Description . Female. Lengths ( holotype ): head 2.0 mm; scutum 1.5 mm ; fore wing 5.4 mm ; body 7.5 mm . Pubescence mostly brownish-white, vertex and anterior region of scutum pale brown (
Fig. 1
a–c), ventral surfaces of tarsi and medioposterior regions of T 4 –T 5 orange (
Fig. 1
c–d). Integument, head above antennal sockets, most of paraocular area adjacent to eye and gena black, supraclypeus, clypeus, most of paraocular area below antennal sockets (yellow markings reaching eye ventrally only), anterior surface of antennal scape and mandible yellow (
Fig. 1
a); mesosoma mostly black, metanotum yellow, legs orange; metasoma orange, except a dark lateral spot on T 2 and pygidial plate blackish (
Fig. 1
b–d), poorly defined blackish areas medially on T 4 –T 5 (
Fig. 1
b–d), S 2 –S 6 extensively blackish, pygidial plate black (
Fig. 1
d). Structure: clypeus convex, shape as in
Fig. 1
a, facial fovea narrow; fore wing with first submarginal cell slightly arched posteriorly; propodeum angulately divided with short, anterior, subhorizontal (clearly sculptured) and long, subvertical, posterior (weakly glabrous) surfaces, cf.
Fig. 4
d.
Male. Unknown.
Distribution . This species is only known from the type locality in northwest Namibia .

Material Examined . Female holotype and three female paratypes ‘
Namibia , Karibib
: 65 km SW Usakos
1.3 . 1990
, leg. Max Schwarz’, holotype and two paratypes in MSAA , one paratype in SANC .

Meliturgula(Meliturgula) braunsi Friese
(
Fig. 2
a–e)

South Africa . Foraging on flowers of:
Mesembryanthemum
sp.,
Ruschia uncinata
( Mesembryanthemaceae )

subSubSection.paragraph:
Meliturgula (Meliturgula) scriptifrons (Walker)
(
Fig. 4
)

Angola ; Botswana , Eritrea ; Kenya ; Malawi ; Namibia , South Africa , Sudan ; Tanzania ; Zimbabwe , Palaearctic. Foraging on flowers of:
Gisekia Africana (
Gisekiaceae
), Heliotropium rariflorum (
Boraginaceae
), Heeria paniculosa (
Anacardiaceae
), Indigofera auricoma , Indigofera rautanenii , Indigofera
sp. ( Fabaceae ),
Justicia
sp. ( Anacardiaceae ), Mesembrythanthemum sp. ( Mesembryanthemaceae ),
Ocimum americanum (
Lamiaceae
), Ozoroa paniculosa
var. salicina
( Anacardiaceae ) ,
Senna italica (
Asteraceae
), Tribulus cristatus (
Zygophyllaceae
), Zygophyllum simplex (
Zygophyllaceae ).

(
Fig. 5
)

Namibia . Foraging on flowers of:
Tribulus
sp. ( Zygophyllaceae ).

;

subSubSection.paragraph:
Meliturgula (Poecilomelitta) eardleyana Patiny
(
Fig. 6
) Namibia , South Africa .

Meliturgula eardleyana
is intermediate between
M. fuliginosa
and
M. rozeni
. The male face resembles
M. rozeni
whereas the male metasomal terminalia are like those of
M. fuliginosa
. The female face resembles that of
M. fuliginosa
. This is the first description of the male of
M. eardleyana .

Diagnosis . Male. Anterior surface of antennal scape, lower surface of antennal flagellum and most of clypeus yellow, ventrolateral corner of clypeus black (
Fig. 6
c), eye moderately large (
Fig. 6
c).
Description . Female. As described by Patiny ( 2000 ).

Male. Lengths: head 1.4 mm ; scutum 0.9 mm ; fore wing 3.8 mm ; body 5.0 mm. Pubescence mostly white (
Fig. 6
c–d), ventral surfaces of tarsi pale yellow (
Fig. 6
d). Integument black, except yellow on anterior surface of scape, ventral surfaces of basal five segments of flagellum (distal six segments brownish-yellow below), most of clypeus (ventrolateral corner of clypeus black), and all tarsi (
Fig. 6
c–d). Structure: vertex, frontal view, eyes moderately large ( 0.6 x as wide as face at antennal socket level); eyes converge above (upper interorbital distance 0.83 x lower interorbital distance); inner eye margins distinctly convex (
Fig. 6
c); antennal scape reaching lateral ocellus; scape about 7.5 x as long as flagellar segment 1 , which is twice as long as flagellar segment 2 ; flagellum reaches to about middle of scutum; labrum with median region concave, apical margin recessed, shiny, mediolateral region punctuate; S 6 with posteromedian, bifurcate spine (
Fig. 6
e); S 7 as in
M. scriptifrons (
Eardley 1991
)
, S 8 and genital capsule as in
M. fuliginosa (
Eardley 1991
)
.
Distribution . This species is known from the type locality in the Karoo, South Africa , and the middle of Namibia .

Material Examined . Male: Namibia , 42km S. Maltahohe, 25.00S
16.45 E
,
17 .ii. 1988
, G.D. Butler, in SANC .
